text: The first thing is just recognizing that this is related to search. So it's LLM plus RAG, it's summarizing a set of search results usually. So LLM plus RAG, number one. Number two is topics. So in search, a landing page is targeting hundreds of keywords, which we talked about on the last podcast.
speaker: Ethan Smith
context: Lenny asks Ethan what are the most important things for people to understand to be successful in Answer Engine Optimization (AEO). Ethan explains that AEO works through LLM plus RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation), meaning the AI model searches for and then summarizes multiple sources rather than just using its training data. He emphasizes that like traditional SEO, each page should target broad topics with hundreds or thousands of related keywords and questions, not just single terms.
text_ko: 먼저 이건 검색과 관련돼 있다는 걸 인지하는 게 중요해요. 보통 대형 언어 모델(LLM)과 RAG(Retrieval-Augmented Generation)이 결합돼서 검색 결과들을 요약하는 식이에요. 그래서 LLM과 RAG가 첫 번째이고요. 두 번째는 토픽(topics)이에요. 검색에서는 랜딩 페이지(landing page)가 수백 개의 키워드(keywords)를 한꺼번에 타깃팅한다는 점인데, 이건 지난 팟캐스트(podcast)에서 얘기했던 내용이에요.
text_zh: 首先得明白，这个其实就是跟搜索有关的。就是大语言模型(LLM)加上检索增强生成(RAG)，通常就是把一堆搜索结果给总结一下。所以第一点就是LLM加RAG。第二点是话题性。在搜索这块儿，一个落地页(landing page)要针对几百个关键词，这个我们在上期播客里聊过。
text_es: Lo primero es simplemente reconocer que esto está relacionado con las búsquedas. O sea, es LLM más RAG, básicamente está resumiendo un conjunto de resultados de búsqueda. Entonces, LLM más RAG, ese es el punto número uno. El número dos son los temas. En las búsquedas, una página de destino (landing page) está dirigida a cientos de palabras clave, que ya comentamos en el podcast anterior.
key_sentence: LLM plus RAG summarizes a set of search results targeting hundreds of keywords.

text: That's not the case for Answer Engine Optimization, because you can get mentioned by a citation tomorrow and start showing up immediately. You can have a Reddit thread, you can have a YouTube video. You can be mentioned on a blog, like a brand-new YC company launches, everyone's talking about them. They could show up in an answer tomorrow as a result of that. So early-stage companies can win, they can win quickly.
speaker: Ethan Smith
context: Lenny and Ethan are discussing how AEO differs from traditional SEO for startups. Ethan explains that traditional SEO requires significant domain authority that takes time to build, making it unsuitable for early-stage companies. However, with AEO, companies can appear in AI-generated answers immediately by getting mentioned in various online sources, without needing to build up domain authority first.
text_ko: 그건 답변 엔진 최적화(Answer Engine Optimization)의 경우는 달라요. 내일 누군가 언급(인용)해주기만 해도 바로 답변에 나타나기 시작할 수 있어요. 레딧 스레드가 올라가거나 유튜브 영상이 생기거나 블로그에 언급되는 것만으로도 가능해요. 예컨대 막 와이컴비네이터(YC) 신생 기업이 런칭해서 모두가 그 얘기를 하고 있다면, 그 영향으로 내일 당장 답변에 등장할 수 있어요. 그래서 초기 단계의 회사들은 승산이 있어요, 그것도 아주 빠르게요.
text_zh: 但答案引擎优化(Answer Engine Optimization)就不是这样了，你明天就可能被引用，然后马上就能出现在结果里。你可以有个Reddit帖子，可以有个YouTube视频，也可以在博客上被提到，比如一家刚成立的YC公司上线了，大家都在讨论他们，结果他们明天就可能出现在答案里。所以初创公司是有机会的，而且能赢得很快。
text_es: Pero con la Optimización para Motores de Respuesta (Answer Engine Optimization) es diferente, porque te pueden mencionar en una cita mañana y empezar a aparecer de inmediato. Puedes tener un hilo en Reddit, puedes tener un video de YouTube. Te pueden mencionar en un blog, como cuando se lanza una nueva empresa de YC y todo mundo está hablando de ellos. Pueden aparecer en una respuesta mañana como resultado de eso. Así que las empresas en etapa temprana sí pueden ganar, y pueden ganar rápido.
key_sentence: Early-stage companies can win quickly by getting mentioned by a citation and showing up immediately.

text: They are significantly more valuable. So Webflow, we saw a 6X conversion rate difference between LLM traffic and Google Search traffic. Six times so significantly more qualified. I think that's probably for a couple of reasons. Probably it's because you're so primed because you're having a conversation with multiple follow-ups, and so there's so much intent that you've built.
speaker: Ethan Smith
context: Lenny asks whether leads from answer engines like ChatGPT are actually valuable for B2B SaaS companies. Ethan shares data from their work with Webflow showing that visitors from AI platforms convert at six times the rate of Google Search traffic. He explains this higher conversion rate is likely due to the conversational nature of AI interactions, where users build intent through multiple follow-up questions before clicking through to a website.
vocabulary_highlights: so much intent that you've built
text_ko: 그 트래픽이 훨씬 더 가치가 있었어요. 예를 들어 Webflow에서는 대형 언어 모델(LLM) 트래픽이 구글 검색(Google Search) 트래픽보다 전환율이 6배나 높게 나왔어요. 즉 훨씬 더 적합한(qualified) 트래픽이었던 거죠. 아마 그건 몇 가지 이유가 있는데, 특히 대화를 여러 차례 이어가며 후속 질문(follow-ups)이 쌓이기 때문에 사용자가 이미 충분히 프라이밍(prime)돼 있고 그만큼 의도(intent)가 많이 형성돼 있기 때문인 것 같아요.
text_zh: 这些流量的价值要高得多。就拿Webflow来说，我们发现LLM流量和谷歌搜索流量的转化率差了6倍。整整6倍，质量明显更高。我觉得可能有几个原因。主要是因为用户已经被充分"预热"了，他们跟AI有过多轮对话，来来回回问了很多问题，所以购买意向(intent)已经建立得很充分了。
text_es: Son significativamente más valiosos. O sea, en Webflow vimos una diferencia de 6 veces en la tasa de conversión entre el tráfico de LLM y el tráfico de búsqueda de Google. Seis veces más cualificado, ¿eh? Creo que esto se debe a un par de razones. Probablemente es porque ya vienes preparado porque estás teniendo una conversación con varias preguntas de seguimiento, entonces has construido muchísima intención de compra.
key_sentence: LLM traffic is significantly more qualified, showing six times the conversion rate of Google Search.

text: The obvious strategy for a growth person is, 'Let's make a bunch of automated spam and spam Reddit all over the place and get my product to show up everywhere.' That's the growth mindset, which makes sense, the hustle mindset. So what are people looking at? They're looking at creating hundreds of fake Reddit accounts pretending to be someone that you're not.
speaker: Ethan Smith
context: Ethan is explaining why Reddit is heavily cited in AI responses and the temptation for companies to game the system. He describes the obvious but flawed strategy many growth marketers consider - creating fake Reddit accounts to spam promotional content. This approach fails because Reddit's community is good at detecting and removing spam, and authentic engagement is what actually works for getting cited in AI responses.
vocabulary_highlights: spam Reddit all over the place
text_ko: 그로스 담당자(growth person)가 택하는 뻔한 전략은 "자동화된 대량 스팸(spam)을 만들어 레딧(Reddit) 여기저기 뿌려 우리 제품을 어디서든 보이게 하자" 하는 거예요. 그게 바로 성장 마인드셋(growth mindset)이죠 — 말이 되긴 해요, 허슬 마인드셋(hustle mindset)이니까요. 그래서 결국 사람들이 하는 건 수백 개의 가짜 레딧(Reddit) 계정을 만들어 본인이 아닌 다른 사람인 척 활동하는 거예요.
text_zh: 做增长的人最容易想到的套路就是，"咱们搞一堆自动化的垃圾信息，到处刷Reddit，让我的产品满天飞。" 这就是典型的增长思维(growth mindset)，也就是那种拼命折腾的心态(hustle mindset)，听起来挺有道理的。所以这些人在干嘛呢？他们在批量注册几百个假的Reddit账号，装成别人。
text_es: La estrategia obvia para alguien enfocado en crecimiento es: "Hagamos un montón de spam automatizado y llenemos Reddit por todos lados para que mi producto aparezca en todas partes." Esa es la mentalidad de crecimiento (growth mindset), que tiene sentido, la mentalidad del hustle. Entonces, ¿qué está haciendo la gente? Están creando cientos de cuentas falsas de Reddit, haciéndose pasar por alguien que no son.
key_sentence: The growth mindset leads to spam Reddit all over the place with fake accounts.

text: So the Reddit strategy is the obvious strategy, which is just to be an actual user of Reddit. Make an account, say who you are, say where you work, and give a useful answer. And that sounds simple if you're not in the growth mindset of, 'I need to scale this to hundreds of comments.' But you don't actually need 10,000 comments, even five could be great and that scales perfectly well.
speaker: Ethan Smith
context: Ethan is contrasting the failed spam approach to Reddit with the successful strategy for getting mentioned in AI citations. Instead of trying to scale fake engagement, he recommends authentic participation where company representatives transparently identify themselves and provide genuinely helpful answers to Reddit discussions. This authentic approach works better than mass automation because quality matters more than quantity.
text_ko: Reddit 전략은 사실 가장 당연한 전략이에요: 그냥 실제 Reddit 사용자처럼 행동하면 돼요. 계정 하나 만들고 누구인지, 어디서 일하는지 밝히고 유용한 답변을 해 주세요. '이걸 수백 개의 댓글로 키워야 해'라는 식의 성장 마인드셋(growth mindset)에 빠져 있지 않다면 아주 단순하게 느껴질 거예요. 사실 1만 개의 댓글이 필요한 건 아니고, 다섯 개만 있어도 훌륭할 수 있고 그 정도면 충분히 확장(scale)돼요.
text_zh: 所以Reddit的策略其实很简单明了，就是你真的去当个Reddit用户。注册个账号，说明你是谁，在哪工作，然后给出有用的回答。如果你不是抱着"我得把这个规模化到几百条评论"的增长思维，这听起来就很简单。但实际上你根本不需要发一万条评论，哪怕就五条也能很棒，而且这样的规模完全够用。
text_es: Entonces la estrategia de Reddit es la estrategia obvia, que es simplemente ser un usuario real de Reddit. Te haces una cuenta, dices quién eres, dices dónde trabajas, y das una respuesta útil. Y eso suena sencillo si no estás en la mentalidad de crecimiento (growth mindset) de "necesito escalar esto a cientos de comentarios." Pero la verdad es que no necesitas 10,000 comentarios, incluso cinco pueden ser geniales y eso escala perfectamente bien.
key_sentence: Be an actual user of Reddit; five comments can scale perfectly well without the growth mindset.

text: Google's slice of the pie stays the same. The pie gets bigger. And so misinformation about Google going down, Google is not going down. Google published something recently, their VP of search explicitly said, 'I looked at the traffic that we're sending to publishers, and it is not down, it's up slightly.'
speaker: Ethan Smith
context: Ethan is addressing common misinformation about AI and search, specifically the narrative that Google Search is dying due to AI-powered answer engines. He explains that new search surfaces like TikTok, Instagram, and now AI chatbots don't replace Google - they expand the total market for search and discovery. Google continues to send traffic to publishers, contradicting claims that AI overviews are killing traditional search traffic.
vocabulary_highlights: Google's slice of the pie stays the same
text_ko: 구글의 시장 점유율(share)은 그대로예요. 대신 전체 파이(pie)가 커지고 있는 거예요. 그래서 '구글이 망한다'는 식의 오해가 퍼지고 있는데, 그건 사실이 아니에요. 구글이 하락하고 있는 게 아니라는 거예요. 구글도 최근에 발표했고, 검색 담당 부사장(VP of Search)이 직접 "퍼블리셔(publishers)에 보내는 트래픽(traffic)을 봤는데 줄지 않았고, 오히려 약간 늘었다"고 말했어요.
text_zh: 谷歌的市场份额还是那样，没变。但整个市场盘子变大了。所以那些说谷歌要完蛋的消息都是瞎传，谷歌根本没有下滑。谷歌最近发了个声明，他们搜索业务的VP明确说过：'我看了我们给发布商导的流量，不但没降，还略微涨了一点。'
text_es: La porción del pastel que tiene Google sigue igual. Pero el pastel se hace más grande. Entonces toda esa desinformación de que Google está cayendo, Google no se está cayendo para nada. Google publicó algo hace poco, su vicepresidente de búsquedas dijo claramente: 'Revisé el tráfico que les estamos enviando a los editores, y no está bajando, de hecho está subiendo un poquito.'
key_sentence: Google's slice of the pie stays the same, despite misinformation about its traffic going down.
